chapter.title: Installing with the &install_ui;
chapter.para: &kw-hos-phrase; comes with a graphical user interface (GUI) installer for installing your cloud for the first time; it is not suitable for upgrades. It offers several input model examples of typical cloud configurations to choose from. Based on your specific choice, the &install_ui; presents only those fields and decisions that are necessary for entering your information. When complete, the &install_ui; generates accurate and complete configuration files to be deployed, and installs the cloud with that configuration.

Configuring without the &install_ui; requires identifying and manually editing the proper YAML (.yml) files, making sure that the information is in the correct location in each file, maintaining strict YAML format in the files, and then determining and running correct playbooks. The &install_ui; is designed to make the initial installation process simpler, more accurate and less time consuming than manual installation.

The &install_ui; populates configuration files that the configuration processor uses as input. You can inspect the files at any time, including just prior to actually configuring your cloud. Configuration files are periodically saved in the background during the process.

When you click the Deploy button at the end of the process, the complete configuration will be implemented. This means that if you change anything directly in the files themselves during the &install_ui; installation process, those values will be overwritten by values you have entered with the &install_ui;. It also means that you can stop the installation process before clicking Deploy to see how the YAML files have been configured. Version control for these YAML configuration files is managed in a git repository, as explained in .

Configuration information can be provided to the &install_ui; manually and by CSV import. The &install_ui; can also discover information from &susemgr; and &oneview;. Using that input, Cobbler and Ansible scripts provision and deploy &productname;.

When installing via the &install_ui;, you begin with one of 8 input model examples (cloud configuration templates) and are guided step-by-step to provide specifications that determine your cloud environment.

The full range of customizations is not possible using the &install_ui;. Some customizations require editing the yml files, which is done from the "Review Configuration Files" page of the &install_ui;. Below is the list of what can be changed within the &install_ui;, followed by a list of customizations that can only be changed by directly editing the files.

section.title: Before You Begin
section.para: Before you run the &install_ui; to install your cloud, there are a number of things you need to do:

listitem.para: Choose a configuration template from the . No action other than an understanding of your needs is necessary at this point. In the &install_ui; you will indicate which input model example you wish to deploy .
Before you use the &install_ui; to install your cloud, you may install the operating system, &hlinux;, on your nodes (servers) if you choose. Otherwise, the &install_ui; will install it for you.

If you are installing the operating system on all your nodes yourself, you must do so using the &hlinux; image that is included in the &kw-hos-phrase; package. The instructions on the following pages may be helpful even when installing the operating system on your own:

When following the guidance for operating system installation on those pages, stop before the sections for .
The &install_ui; will run those steps, and if you have the &install_ui; also install the operating systems, it will run all the previous steps (playbooks) as well.

section.title: Running the &install_ui; to Install Your Cloud
section.para: The &install_ui; is found on the &lcm; node at: http://LIFECYCLE_MANAGER_IP:3000

To create a secure tunnel/port forwarding into Apache from the &lcm; in order to use the &install_ui; in a browser, SSH tunnel into the &lcm; with the username/password set up when installing the &lcm;. The username and password should be what was set in . For example:
On your local machine (the one you are tunneling from) point your browser to: http://localhost:8080 . If the connection is interrupted, then you should refresh your browser.
The first page of the &install_ui; shows the general installation process and a reminder to gather some information before beginning. Clicking the Next button brings up the Model Selection page.

The input model examples are displayed on this page. Details of each model can be seen on the right by clicking the model name on the left. If you have already decided some aspects of your cloud environment, models can be filtered using the dropdown selections. Narrowing a parameter affects the range of choices of models and changes other dropdown choices to only those that are compatible.

Selecting a model will determine the base template from which the cloud will be deployed. Models can be adjusted later in the process, though selecting the closest match to your requirements reduces the effort required to deploy your cloud.

Based on the cloud example selected on the previous page, more detail is shown about that cloud configuration and the components that will be deployed. Mandatory components have assigned quantities; we strongly suggest not changing those quantities to avoid potential problems later in the installation process. Additional component quantities can be adjusted within the parameters shown. The number of nodes (servers) dedicated to each server role can be adjusted; most models are configured by design to support High Availability and to distribute OpenStack services appropriately.
section.bridgehead: Add Servers and Assign Server Roles
section.para: This page provides more detail about the number and assignment of each type of node based on the information from the previous page (any changes must be made there). Servers may be discovered using &susemgr;, &oneview;, or both. Clicking the Discover button will prompt for access credentials to the system management software to be used for discovery. After validating credentials, Discovery will retrieve a list of known servers from the &susemgr; and/or &oneview; and allow access to server details on those management platforms.

Server information may also be entered manually or imported via CSV in the Manual Entry tab. The format for CSV entry is described above. The server assignment list includes placeholder server details that can be edited to reflect real hardware, or can be removed and replaced with discovered or manually added systems. You may want to read to know more about the server roles shown.
Subnetand netmask values should be set on this page as they may impact the IP addresses being assigned to various servers.
section.bridgehead: Choose servers on which &hlinux; will be installed
section.para: If an OS has not previously been installed on the servers that make up the cloud configuration, the OS installation page allows for Cobbler to deploy &hlinux; on servers in the cloud configuration. Enter credentials, select servers and click Install to deploy &hlinux; to these servers. An installation log and progress indicators will be displayed.

When the OS installation is complete, a Server and Server Role Summary is displayed. It shows which servers have been assigned to each role, and provides an opportunity to edit the server configurations. Various cloud components can be configured by clicking on Manage Cloud Settings dialog. Some general aspects of the cloud (such as NTP servers) can be configured, as well as more specific details such as NIC Mappings and Disk Models.

important.para: Directly changing files may cause the configuration to fail validation. During the process of installing with the &install_ui;, any changes should be made with the tools provided within the &install_ui;.

section.para: Advanced editing of the cloud configuration can be done on the "Review Configuration Files" page. Individual .yml and .J2 files can be edited directly with the embedded editor in the Model and Templates and Services tabs. The Deployment tab covers Wipe Data Disks, Encryption Key and Verbosity Level.

Before performing the deployment, the configuration must be validated by clicking the Validate button below the list of configuration files on the Model tab. This ensures that the configuration will be successful before the actual configuration process runs and possibly fails. If there are issues with the validation, the configuration processor will provide detailed information about the causes. When validation completes successfully a message will be displayed that the model is valid.
Clicking the Deploy button starts the actual deployment process.
General progress steps on shown on the left. Detailed activity is shown on the right.

To start the deployment process, the &install_ui; commits all files to git for version control. It then runs scripts and playbooks based on the actual final configuration. Completed operations are green, black means in process, gray items are not started yet.

When the deployment process is complete, all items on the left will be green. The &install_ui; will report Cloud Deployment Successful and some information about the deployment, including the chosen input model and links to cloud management tools.
When you finish installing, the &install_ui; will be disabled via Ansible. It is also disabled when deployment is completed following the CLI instructions.

section.title: Use the &install_ui; Securely
section.para: The &install_ui; is a web-based application that runs on the &lcm; node and is implemented in ReactJS and Python. This application runs behind Apache 2.0 on port 3000. Browser refresh is not necessary if you are using the browser connected directly to the &install_ui;.
You should access the &install_ui; through Apache. An example URL looks like this: http://LIFE_CYCLE_MANAGER_HOST_IP:3000.

The Horizon Dashboard connection runs over TLS, a protocol that provides secure communications on the Internet. So you should use HTTPS:// to navigate to Horizon with the IP address that the &install_ui; presents when installation is complete.
